In general, one tries to make as many correct predictions as possible. When making an incorrect prediction (FP or FN), we expect misclassification costs. Such misclassification costs can be different, for example 5$ for each False Positive (FP) prediction and 1$ for each False Negative (FN), respectively.

Given these costs, let us imagine the AI algorithm predicts two characteristics (positive or negative) from a set of 20 samples. Our chosen decision threshold Î¸ results in the confusion matrix dispayed below. We expect the following outcomes:

  • 13 correct predictions: 6 True Positives, 7 True Negatives
  • 7 incorrect predictions: 3 False Positives and 4 False Negatives

Confusion Matrix (Absolute Observations)
Predicted Class
Positive Negative
Actual Class Positive 6 4
Negative 3 7

Based thereon, we would expect 3 x 5$ (=15$) for False Positive Predictions and 4 x 1$ (=4$) for False Negative predictions, resulting in 19$ overall. We display the overall costs in the "cost matrix" below.

Predicted Class
Positive Negative
Actual Class Positive - 4
Negative 15 -
